questions.text: Ga-68PSMA is used to diagnose which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - B. Prostate cancer

Ga-68 PSMA (Gallium-68 Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen) is a radiotracer used in PET/CT imaging. It targets the Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen (PSMA), a protein highly expressed in prostate cancer cells. This imaging technique is commonly employed for the detection, staging, and recurrence monitoring of prostate cancer.

questions.text: Whole-body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- C.

CT Limbs

A whole-body CT scan protocol for trauma patients, often referred to as a "trauma CT protocol" or "pan-scan," is designed to rapidly evaluate life-threatening injuries. It typically includes: 

1. CT Head – To assess for brain injuries or skull fractures.

2. CT Cervical Spine – To evaluate for cervical spine injuries.

3. CT Chest, Abdomen, and Pelvis – To identify thoracic and abdominal trauma, including organ injuries or internal bleeding.

CT Limbs is not routinely included in the standard whole-body CT trauma protocol unless there is a specific clinical indication, such as visible deformities or suspected fractures. Limb injuries are usually evaluated with X-rays or targeted CT scans as needed.

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - C. Pancoast tumor

While Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) of the thorax is the primary imaging modality for diagnosing and staging lung carcinomas, MRI is particularly useful for evaluating specific cases like Pancoast tumors. Pancoast tumors are located at the apex of the lung and often invade adjacent structures, such as the brachial plexus, subclavian vessels, or spine.

choices.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the kidney and soft tissue. What is the reason for this super scan appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - B. Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

A super scan appearance on a bone scan is characterized by:
•	Diffuse increased uptake in the skeleton, indicating extensive skeletal involvement.
•	Markedly reduced or absent uptake in the kidneys and soft tissues, as most of the radiotracer is taken up by the extensively involved bones.
In patients with prostate cancer, this pattern typically results from diffuse metastatic involvement of the bones, which is common in advanced stages of the disease. The increased bone turnover in metastatic sites leads to higher radiotracer accumulation.

questions.text: What would be the most likely diagnosis based on X-Ray of a new born child with a scaphoid abdomen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer C. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia The provided X-ray shows classic findings suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). Key features visible include: 1. Bowel loops in the thoracic cavity: These are evident as air-filled structures in the chest, confirming herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. 2. Mediastinal shift: The heart and mediastinal structures are displaced toward the right side. 3. Scaphoid abdomen: This is a clinical finding caused by the absence of abdominal contents in the lower abdomen, as they have herniated into the chest.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A. TLD badge

Personal monitoring of radiation is crucial for individuals who work in environments with exposure to ionizing radiation. This is done using devices specifically designed to measure and record the amount of radiation exposure over a given period.
•	TLD badge (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter): It is the most commonly used personal radiation monitoring device.
•	The badge contains materials (e.g., lithium fluoride) that absorb radiation and store energy.
When heated, these materials release the stored energy as light, and the amount of light emitted is proportional to the radiation dose received. 
Why not the other options?



B. Collimators: These are devices used to focus or restrict the beam of X-rays but are not used for monitoring radiation exposure.
C. Linear accelerator: A device used in radiation therapy to generate high-energy beams, not for personal monitoring.
D. Grid: Used in radiography to reduce scatter radiation and improve image quality but not for monitoring radiation exposure.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage The CT image, combined with the clinical presentation of neck stiffness and severe headache, is most suggestive of SAH. The key clinical signs of neck stiffness and sudden, severe headache ("thunderclap headache") are classic symptoms of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). On CT imaging, SAH typically appears as hyperdense areas (bright white) within the subarachnoid spaces, such as the basal cisterns, sylvian fissures, or ventricles, which can be seen in this image.

questions.text: The structure indicated with the “X” on the given axial CT scan is which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer D. Left ventricle Explanation: The heart chambers are seen as follows (from left to right on the patient's anatomy, corresponding to the image orientation): The left atrium is posterior and slightly superior to the other chambers. The right atrium is located anteriorly and to the right side of the heart. The right ventricle is anterior and sits closer to the sternum.

questions.text: Focal and diffuse thickening of gallbladder wall with high amplitude reflections and ‘comet tail’ artifacts on USG as shown suggest the diagnosis of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - C. Adenomyomatosis The ultrasound (USG) findings of focal and diffuse thickening of the gallbladder wall, high-amplitude reflections, and characteristic "comet tail" artifacts suggest a diagnosis of: Explanation: • Adenomyomatosis is a benign condition of the gallbladder characterized by hyperplasia of the gallbladder wall with intramural diverticula (Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses). • On ultrasound, it presents as: o Diffuse or segmental thickening of the gallbladder wall. o High-amplitude reflections from cholesterol crystals within the sinuses. o Comet tail artifacts, a hallmark of this condition, caused by reverberation from the crystals. Why not the other options? • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis: Shows gallbladder wall thickening, but without comet tail artifacts. It often has hypoechoic nodules or masses within the thickened wall. • Carcinoma of the gallbladder: Presents with irregular gallbladder wall thickening or a mass, and does not produce comet tail artifacts. • Cholesterolosis: Can show a "strawberry gallbladder" appearance but lacks comet tail artifacts.

questions.text: Mount Fuji sign is seen in which of the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - B. Tension Pneumocephalus

Explanation:
The Mount Fuji sign is a radiological finding seen on CT scans of the brain. It refers to the appearance of two widely separated frontal lobes caused by subdural air, resembling the peak of Mount Fuji, in cases of tension pneumocephalus. This condition occurs when air accumulates under pressure in the cranial cavity, leading to compression of the brain structures.
Key Features of the Mount Fuji Sign:
•	Seen in tension pneumocephalus, often a complication of head trauma, neurosurgery, or skull base fractures.
•	Represents air under tension in the subdural or subarachnoid spaces.
•	The frontal lobes are compressed and separated by the accumulated air.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality found in the ultrasound image shown:
questions.solution: Correct Answer – A Phrygian cap: This is a congenital anatomical variant of the gallbladder where the fundus folds over the body. Mercedes-Benz sign: Refers to the gas pattern seen in gallstones that have a fissured appearance, typically on plain X-ray, not ultrasound.

questions.text: Shown finding on USG is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - A. Spina bifida The ultrasound (USG) image shows the classic "lemon-shaped" head appearance, which is commonly associated with: Explanation: • Spina bifida, specifically the open form (myelomeningocele), often presents with secondary features detectable on prenatal ultrasound. • The lemon sign refers to the scalloping or inward concavity of the frontal bones, which gives the head a lemon-like shape. This is a highly specific finding in fetuses with neural tube defects such as spina bifida. • Additional findings may include the "banana sign" (curved cerebellum) and ventriculomegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following modalities use remote afterloading?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - B. Brachytherapy

Explanation:
•	Brachytherapy is a type of internal radiation therapy where radioactive sources are placed close to or inside the tumor.
•	Remote afterloading is a technique used in brachytherapy to enhance safety. In this process:
1.	A catheter or applicator is placed at the treatment site.
2.	The radioactive source is remotely "loaded" into the applicator after the medical staff have left the room, minimizing their exposure to radiation.
3.	Once the treatment is complete, the source is retracted remotely.
Why not the other options?
•	Teletherapy: This involves external beam radiation (e.g., linear accelerator) and does not use afterloading techniques.
•	Radioactive iodine therapy: This is a systemic therapy where iodine-131 is ingested or injected to target thyroid tissue, without any applicators or loading mechanisms.
•	Targeted therapy: This refers to drugs that specifically target molecular pathways in cancer cells and is unrelated to radiation therapy.

questions.text: Shown appearance on cerebral angiography is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer – B Moya moya disease: • Moya moya disease: Characterized by progressive stenosis of cerebral arteries with compensatory formation of abnormal collateral vessels, giving a "puff of smoke" appearance on angiography • Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Typically diagnosed clinically and by MRI/CT; angiography would show obstruction or lack of flow, not dilated abnormal vessels. • ACA aneurysm: Would present as a localized outpouching (aneurysm) of the anterior cerebral artery, which is not visible in this image.

questions.text: A 42 year old male on presents with a ring enhancing sign on his CT brain. The following is his MR spectroscopy image with a lipid peak. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Tuberculoma The CT image shows a ring-enhancing lesion, and the MR spectroscopy reveals a lipid peak, which is most consistent with: Explanation: Tuberculoma (a form of CNS tuberculosis) is a common cause of ring-enhancing lesions in regions where tuberculosis is prevalent. On MR spectroscopy, a lipid peak is characteristic and represents caseous necrosis within the lesion. Ring enhancement on imaging is due to a granulomatous response and a central necrotic core surrounded by a vascularized capsule. Why not the other options? • Canavan disease: A rare metabolic disorder that affects the white matter. It is primarily seen in children, not adults, and MR spectroscopy shows elevated N-acetylaspartate (NAA), not a lipid peak. • Glioma: While gliomas may enhance with contrast, they typically show increased choline (Cho) and reduced N-acetylaspartate (NAA) on spectroscopy, without a prominent lipid peak. • Lymphoma: CNS lymphoma can show ring enhancement, but MR spectroscopy shows increased lipid and choline, along with reduced NAA and creatine (Cr), and it is less common in immunocompetent individuals.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - C. FLAIR image The MRI image shown is a FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) image. Explanation: • FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) is a specialized T2-weighted imaging sequence in which the signal from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is suppressed. This makes it easier to visualize pathological hyperintense signals, such as edema or gliosis, which are otherwise masked by the bright signal of CSF on standard T2-weighted images. Why not the other options? 1. T2-weighted image: o CSF appears bright. o Pathological lesions also appear bright, but without CSF suppression, subtle lesions near the CSF may be less apparent. 2. T1-weighted image: o CSF appears dark, but the overall contrast of tissues is different. o T1-weighted images highlight fat and are used for anatomical detail. 3. STIR (Short Tau Inversion Recovery): o This is typically used for fat suppression, commonly in musculoskeletal imaging, and not for brain imaging.

questions.text: The given finding in MRI is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Joubert syndrome The MRI image shows characteristic findings of the "molar tooth sign," which is seen in: Explanation: • Joubert syndrome is a rare congenital disorder characterized by: o Hypoplasia or aplasia of the cerebellar vermis. o The "molar tooth sign" on MRI, which is due to abnormal thickening and orientation of the superior cerebellar peduncles combined with an abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa. o Associated with developmental delay, hypotonia, oculomotor apraxia, and breathing abnormalities in infancy. Why not the other options? • Multiple system atrophy (MSA): o Neurodegenerative disorder with features like cerebellar atrophy and the "hot cross bun sign," but not the "molar tooth sign." • Refsum disease: o A metabolic disorder involving phytanic acid metabolism, primarily affecting peripheral nerves, retina, and skin. MRI findings are not characteristic of this condition. • Miller Fischer syndrome: o A variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome involving ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia, but it does not have characteristic MRI findings like the "molar tooth sign."

questions.text: Select the correct match:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - A. A-2/B-4/C-1/D-3 A. Bulging fissure sign → Klebsiella pneumoniae (2) o The bulging fissure sign is seen in lobar pneumonia caused by organisms like Klebsiella pneumoniae, where inflammation leads to swelling and displacement of the fissures. B. Water lily sign → Hydatid cyst (4) o The water lily sign is observed in pulmonary hydatid cysts when the endocyst detaches from the pericyst, creating a floating membrane. C. Monod sign → Aspergillosis (1) o The Monod sign, or "air crescent sign," is commonly seen in invasive aspergillosis, particularly when a fungal ball forms within a pre-existing lung cavity. D. Popcorn calcification → Pulmonary hamartoma (3) o Popcorn calcification is a classic radiologic finding in pulmonary hamartomas due to their chondroid calcifications.

questions.text: Which of the following stage of neurocysticercosis is not associated with edema on imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - D. Nodular calcified stage

Neurocysticercosis progresses through several stages, and the presence of edema varies based on the stage:
1.	Vesicular stage:
o	The cyst is viable with little to no surrounding inflammation.
o	No edema is typically seen in this stage.
2.	Colloidal vesicular stage:
o	The cyst begins to degenerate, and there is an inflammatory response.
o	Significant edema is present due to surrounding inflammation.
3.	Granular nodular stage:
o	The cyst continues to degenerate, and inflammation persists.
o	Edema is still present but begins to decrease as the lesion progresses to calcification.
4.	Nodular calcified stage:
o	The cyst is completely calcified and non-viable.
o	No edema is associated with this stage since the inflammatory process has resolved.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with history of 4 weeks of immobilization for fracture femur developed sudden onset of chest pain and hemoptysis. ECG shows S1 Q3 T3 pattern with shown radiological finding. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - C. Pulmonary embolism A 35-year-old male with a history of prolonged immobilization (a risk factor for deep vein thrombosis, DVT) presents with sudden-onset chest pain and hemoptysis. The ECG shows the classic S1Q3T3 pattern, which is commonly associated with acute pulmonary embolism (PE). The CT scan shows findings consistent with PE, such as filling defects in the pulmonary arteries. Supporting features for Pulmonary Embolism: 1. Clinical presentation: o Sudden chest pain, shortness of breath, and hemoptysis are hallmark symptoms of PE. 2. ECG pattern: o The S1Q3T3 pattern indicates right heart strain. This is commonly seen in pulmonary embolism but is not specific. 3. Imaging: o On CT pulmonary angiography (the shown image), filling defects or thrombi in the pulmonary arteries confirm the diagnosis. Other Options: • A. Acute myocardial infarct: o Typically presents with chest pain radiating to the arm or jaw. o ECG changes include ST-segment elevation or depression, not S1Q3T3. • B. Aortic dissection: o Presents with tearing chest pain radiating to the back. o CT angiography would show an intimal flap. • D. Cor pulmonale: o This is a chronic condition involving right heart failure secondary to lung disease. It does not present acutely.

questions.text: Based on the radiological finding what would be the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer – B Ewings Explanation: Ewing’s sarcoma:Usually appears as a permeative lesion with an "onion skin" periosteal reaction.

questions.text: Based on the radiological image what would be the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - C. Abdominal aortic dissection o The CT scan shows a clear dissection flap within the abdominal aorta, dividing it into two lumens (true and false lumens). This is a hallmark feature of aortic dissection. o The location of the dissection is within the abdominal aorta, not the ascending or descending thoracic aorta.

questions.text: A woman presented with confusion, constipation, and headache. Her serum calcium level was 13.1 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which imaging modality is preferred?
questions.solution: Answer - D. Sestamibi scan : Primary Hyperparathyroidism: o It is most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma, leading to excessive parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion, which raises serum calcium levels and causes symptoms like confusion, constipation, headache, and other signs of hypercalcemia. o Elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) may indicate increased bone turnover due to hyperparathyroidism. o Sestamibi scan (Tc-99m sestamibi) is the imaging modality of choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome presents with symptoms of severe headaches and difficulty maintaining balance. An MRI of the brain has been conducted. Which intracranial tumor is most likely contributing to these symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Hemangioblastoma : 1. Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) Syndrome: o VHL is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple benign and malignant tumors, most commonly hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. o Hemangioblastomas are highly associated with VHL and are typically found in the cerebellum, spinal cord, and retina. 2. Clinical Symptoms: o Severe headaches and difficulty maintaining balance (ataxia) strongly suggest a posterior fossa lesion, such as a cerebellar tumor. o In VHL patients, cerebellar hemangioblastomas are a common finding. 3. MRI Findings: o Hemangioblastomas appear as cystic lesions with an enhancing mural nodule. o The image shows a cerebellar lesion consistent with the characteristic findings of a hemangioblastoma. 4. Differential Diagnosis: o A. Acoustic neuroma: Typically involves the cerebellopontine angle and is associated with hearing loss and tinnitus, not ataxia. o C. Meningioma: Extra-axial tumor, often found near the dura, and less common in VHL. o D. Pilocytic astrocytoma: Common in children and young adults, presenting as cystic lesions with a mural nodule, but not typically associated with VHL.

questions.text: Most important advantage of Transcranial USG:
questions.solution:
Answer - C. Detect vasospasm

Transcranial Ultrasound (TCD - Transcranial Doppler) is a non-invasive imaging modality that evaluates cerebral blood flow and dynamic changes in the major intracranial arteries.
Detect Vasospasm:
o	It is the most important advantage of TCD, especially in patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Vasospasm leads to increased blood flow velocity, which can be detected and monitored using TCD.
o	It is non-invasive and allows for continuous bedside monitoring.

questions.text: Shown finding is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer – C Warfarin Warfarin use during pregnancy may cause fetal warfarin syndrome, leading to skeletal abnormalities, but they are distinct and include stippled epiphyses and nasal hypoplasia.

questions.text: Identify the investigation and diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - C. RGU, Bulbar urethral stricture : 1. Investigation: Retrograde Urethrography (RGU) o The provided image is from a Retrograde Urethrography (RGU). o RGU is a diagnostic imaging technique where contrast is introduced retrogradely into the urethra to assess its anatomy and look for abnormalities such as strictures. 2. Diagnosis: Bulbar Urethral Stricture o The narrowing seen in the bulbar urethra indicates a stricture, which is a focal narrowing of the urethral lumen caused by fibrosis/scarring. o This is a common location for urethral strictures due to trauma, infection, or iatrogenic causes.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with confusion. He takes antihypertensive medication and aspirin following a recent myocardial infarction. He remembers a minor fall from a chair three weeks ago, but his neurological exam is otherwise normal. Diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Chronic subdural hematoma : 1. Clinical Presentation: o Elderly Patient: At 76 years old, the patient is in a high-risk group for subdural hematomas due to brain atrophy, which stretches the bridging veins. o History of Fall: The minor fall 3 weeks ago is a classic antecedent for chronic subdural hematoma, as it often follows a delayed course. o Confusion: Neurological symptoms like confusion without a focal neurological deficit are typical in chronic subdural hematomas. o Antiplatelet Use: Aspirin use increases the risk of bleeding. 2. Radiological Findings: o The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped, hypodense collection overlying the brain, consistent with a chronic subdural hematoma. Over time, subdural hematomas become hypodense (low attenuation) as the blood ages and liquefies. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: 1. A. Subarachnoid Hematoma: o Subarachnoid hemorrhage typically presents with a sudden, severe headache ("thunderclap headache") and is not associated with a crescent-shaped collection on CT. 2. C. Extradural Hematoma: o Extradural (epidural) hematomas are typically lens-shaped (biconvex) and associated with trauma causing skull fractures. They present with a lucid interval followed by rapid neurological decline, which is not the case here. 3. D. Diffuse Axonal Injury: o Diffuse axonal injury occurs in severe traumatic brain injuries (e.g., high-speed accidents) and is characterized by widespread axonal damage, not a localized crescent-shaped collection.

questions.text: Reduced uptake in FDG-PET scan is seen In:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - B. Typical carcinoid

1.	FDG-PET (Fluorodeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography):
o	FDG-PET measures glucose metabolism, which is usually higher in aggressive and rapidly dividing tumors.
o	Tumors with low metabolic activity, such as typical carcinoids, show reduced uptake of FDG.
2.	Typical vs. Atypical Carcinoid:
o	Typical carcinoids are low-grade neuroendocrine tumors with slow growth and low metabolic activity, resulting in reduced FDG uptake.
o	Atypical carcinoids are intermediate-grade tumors that may exhibit increased FDG uptake due to their relatively higher metabolic activity.
3.	Other Tumors:
o	Small cell carcinoma: Highly aggressive with high metabolic activity; shows significant FDG uptake.
o	Large cell neuroendocrine tumor: Aggressive and metabolically active, resulting in high FDG uptake.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. The X-ray image is given. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Cephalohematoma 1. Cephalohematoma: o Definition: A collection of blood beneath the periosteum of a cranial bone. o Characteristics:  Confined to the bone boundaries (does not cross sutures due to periosteal attachment).  Commonly seen in neonates after birth trauma.  Presents as a firm, non-tender swelling over the skull. o Radiological Finding:  A localized swelling is visible on X-ray over the affected bone. 2. Subgaleal Hematoma: o Collection of blood beneath the aponeurosis of the scalp. o It is not confined to bone boundaries and can cross sutures. o More extensive swelling compared to cephalohematoma. 3. Caput Succedaneum: o Soft tissue edema of the scalp, typically crosses sutures. o Resolves spontaneously in a few days after birth and does not persist for months. 4. Encephalocele: o Herniation of brain tissue and meninges through a defect in the skull. o Associated with a visible defect in the bone on X-ray, which is absent in this case.

questions.text: Young male presented with fever, ear ache and seizures. He has been having ear discharge since 3 months. MRI brain with contrast shows:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Brain abscess 1. Clinical Presentation: o A young male with:  Fever  Chronic ear discharge (3 months)  Earache  Seizures o This suggests spread of infection, likely from the ear to the brain (commonly through contiguous spread, e.g., otitis media or mastoiditis). 2. Radiological Findings: o The MRI brain (or CT in this case) shows a lesion with:  Rim enhancement on contrast.  Central hypodensity (necrosis) with surrounding edema.  This pattern is characteristic of a brain abscess. 3. Differential Diagnoses: o Neurocysticercosis:  Multiple cystic lesions with a scolex.  Usually associated with calcifications, which are absent here. o Herpes infection:  Involves temporal lobes.  MRI shows hyperintensity and enhancement in temporal regions, not localized abscesses. o Meningioma:  Extra-axial (outside brain parenchyma) lesion.  Homogeneous enhancement with a dural tail, not a rim-enhancing lesion.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with sudden onset weakness of left half of her body since 1 hour. Her alert son promptly brings her to the hospital. The first investigation she should undergo in this setting is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - A. CT Brain 

1.	Clinical Presentation:
o	A 56-year-old woman with sudden onset left-sided weakness suggests an acute stroke.
o	Time is critical in stroke management. The goal is to determine if the stroke is ischemic or hemorrhagic, as treatment differs significantly.
2.	First Investigation:
o	A non-contrast CT (NCCT) brain is the first-line investigation for acute stroke because:
	It is quick and widely available.
	It can immediately rule out hemorrhage (hyperdense area).
	Ischemic changes may not be visible in the early hours, but the absence of hemorrhage allows thrombolysis to be considered.

questions.text: A 42 year old male patient on long term steroid therapy for a systemic disease, presents with recent onset of severe pain in the right hip. The imaging modality of choice for this problem is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - A. MRI scan

1.	Clinical Presentation:
o	A 42-year-old male on long-term steroid therapy presents with severe hip pain.
o	This raises concern for avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head, a well-known complication of chronic steroid use.
2.	Imaging Modality of Choice:
o	MRI scan is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for diagnosing early avascular necrosis:
	It can detect early ischemic changes in the bone marrow before structural changes appear on X-ray or CT.
	It provides detailed images of bone, cartilage, and surrounding soft tissues.

questions.text: The imaging modality shown here is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. PET-CT 1. Image Description: o The provided image shows a whole-body scan with bright, color-coded regions indicating areas of high metabolic activity. o This is characteristic of a PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-Computed Tomography) scan. 2. PET-CT Overview: o PET-CT combines functional imaging (PET) with anatomical imaging (CT). o It uses a radioactive tracer (commonly FDG, a glucose analog) to detect areas of increased metabolic activity, often seen in:  Cancer (tumor evaluation, metastases).  Infections or inflammatory processes.  Certain neurological and cardiac conditions.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male with RTA was brought to the emergency room. On examination, his GCS was E2M2V3. NCCT was performed and was shown. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer - A. Diffuse axonal injury 1. Image Analysis: o The non-contrast CT (NCCT) image shows small, punctate hemorrhages in the white matter regions (arrows indicate areas of injury). o These findings are highly suggestive of Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI), which is characterized by widespread microscopic damage to axons following traumatic brain injury. 2. Key Clinical Features: o The patient has a history of RTA (Road Traffic Accident) and presents with a low GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of E2M2V3. o Such a presentation is consistent with severe brain injury, often associated with DAI. 3. Why not the other options?: o Post-concussion syndrome (Option B):  This is a clinical diagnosis with symptoms like headache, dizziness, and cognitive impairment without visible CT findings. o Extra-dural hemorrhage (Option C):  This would appear as a biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on CT, typically localized. o Intracranial hemorrhage (Option D):  While it may present with hemorrhages, the pattern in the image (multiple small hemorrhages in white matter) is specific to DAI rather than focal bleeding. 4. Diffuse Axonal Injury Overview: o Cause: Rotational/shearing forces during trauma (e.g., RTA). o Findings on Imaging:  CT Scan: Small hemorrhages in white matter, corpus callosum, or brainstem.  MRI: More sensitive, showing abnormalities in the same regions, often using gradient echo (GRE) or SWI sequences. o Clinical Presentation: Low GCS, loss of consciousness, and poor neurological recovery.

questions.text: A young child presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. X-ray is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Morgagni hernia 1. Image Analysis: o The X-ray chest demonstrates a radiopaque shadow near the right hemidiaphragm with displacement of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. o This is characteristic of a Morgagni hernia, which typically presents as an anterior diaphragmatic hernia. 2. Key Features of Morgagni Hernia: o Occurs through the foramen of Morgagni, located anteriorly in the diaphragm (near the sternum). o Commonly presents as a right-sided hernia. o Abdominal contents, such as bowel loops or omental fat, herniate into the thoracic cavity. 3. Why not the other options? o Bochdalek hernia (Option A):  A congenital diaphragmatic hernia that occurs posteriorly, usually on the left side.  It is associated with severe respiratory distress in neonates rather than mild symptoms in children. o Hiatus hernia (Option C):  Involves herniation of the stomach through the esophageal hiatus.  It typically presents with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux and is not evident on plain chest X-rays. o Lung abscess (Option D):  Appears as a localized air-fluid level within the lung parenchyma, which is not seen in this case. 4. Clinical Context: o The patient is a young child with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain, which aligns with the diagnosis of a Morgagni hernia. o This condition can be asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms, such as abdominal discomfort or respiratory issues.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct match regarding the unit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - C. Radioactivity: Becqueral

Matching of Units with Quantities:
1.	Radioactivity: Becquerel (Bq)
o	The Becquerel is the SI unit of radioactivity.
o	It represents one disintegration per second.
2.	Total Radiation Exposure: Coulomb/kg
o	The correct unit for radiation exposure is Coulomb/kg, not Gray.
3.	Absorbed Dose: Gray (Gy)
o	Absorbed dose is measured in Gray (Gy), not Coulomb/kg.
o	1 Gy = 1 joule of energy absorbed per kilogram of material.
4.	Dose Equivalent: Sievert (Sv)
o	The correct unit for dose equivalent (biological effect of radiation) is Sievert (Sv), not Rad.

questions.text: USG of a neonate who is being evaluated for urinary abnormalities reveals the presence of shown finding. What is the investigation of choice for confirming the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - A. MCU (Micturating CystoUrethrogram) The ultrasound (USG) image provided demonstrates a dilated urinary bladder and possibly posterior urethral dilatation, which are indicative of posterior urethral valves (PUV) — a congenital obstruction in the male urethra. Key Points: • Posterior Urethral Valves (PUV): o Common cause of urinary tract abnormalities in neonates, especially males. o Leads to bladder distension, hydronephrosis, and impaired kidney function if not treated. o Confirmed by Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU), which visualizes the posterior urethral obstruction and reflux if present.

questions.text: Based on these CC and ML magnification views of the right breast, what is the MOST appropriate BI-RADS assessment category?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - D. 4 The images provided are magnification views (craniocaudal and mediolateral projections) of the right breast. These show suspicious architectural distortion or microcalcifications, raising concern for malignancy. BI-RADS Categories: • BI-RADS 0: Incomplete — requires additional imaging. • BI-RADS 2: Benign findings (e.g., simple cysts, fibroadenomas). • BI-RADS 3: Probably benign — follow-up recommended (≤2% chance of malignancy). • BI-RADS 4: Suspicious — requires biopsy (>2%–95% chance of malignancy). o This category can be sub-classified:  4A: Low suspicion.  4B: Moderate suspicion.  4C: High suspicion.

questions.text: This 70-year-old patient presents with the insidious onset of heart failure. What is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - D. Constrictive pericarditis The CT image provided shows features of constrictive pericarditis, which is characterized by a thickened and possibly calcified pericardium. This condition leads to diastolic dysfunction due to the restricted filling of the ventricles. Why constrictive pericarditis is the likely diagnosis: 1. Clinical Presentation: o Insidious onset of heart failure in an elderly patient is suggestive of a chronic process. o Symptoms are predominantly related to right-sided heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, ascites, elevated jugular venous pressure). 2. Imaging Features: o CT findings often show thickened pericardium (>4 mm) and sometimes calcifications. o This distinguishes it from restrictive cardiomyopathy, where the myocardium itself is the primary problem. 3. Pathophysiology: o Constrictive pericarditis restricts the heart's diastolic expansion due to a rigid pericardium, leading to increased venous pressures and low cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following is MOST commonly associated with the abnormality demonstrated in the associated image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - A. Unilateral renal agenesis The MRI image demonstrates a uterus didelphys, characterized by two uterine cavities due to failure of complete fusion of the Müllerian ducts during embryogenesis. This condition is commonly associated with unilateral renal agenesis because both the urinary and reproductive systems develop from the intermediate mesoderm and share embryological origins. Why unilateral renal agenesis is the likely association: 1. Embryological Basis: o Müllerian anomalies like uterus didelphys occur due to developmental errors during the formation, fusion, or resorption of the Müllerian ducts. o Since the Wolffian (mesonephric) ducts are crucial for kidney formation, renal anomalies often accompany Müllerian anomalies. 2. Most Common Association: o Among all congenital renal anomalies, unilateral renal agenesis is most frequently associated with uterus didelphys.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with widespread focal osteolytic lesions on radiographs which are F-18 FDG PET positive and Tc-99m-MDP negative. Which of the following is MOST likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer – D. Multiple myeloma. 

The described findings are characteristic of multiple myeloma, a plasma cell malignancy.
1.	Focal Osteolytic Lesions:
o	Multiple myeloma commonly presents with widespread focal osteolytic lesions, as it involves the replacement of normal bone by plasma cells, leading to localized bone destruction.
2.	F-18 FDG PET Positive:
o	PET scans show increased glucose metabolism in active myeloma lesions, which are metabolically hyperactive.
3.	Tc-99m-MDP Bone Scan Negative:
o	Bone scans detect osteoblastic activity, which is typically absent in multiple myeloma because the disease is purely osteolytic, not osteoblastic. Hence, Tc-99m-MDP scans may appear normal or negative.
Why the Other Options are Less Likely:
1.	A. Metastatic Bronchogenic Carcinoma:
o	Bronchogenic carcinoma metastases can be FDG-PET positive but are usually a mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic pattern on imaging, and Tc-99m-MDP bone scans are often positive in metastatic disease.
2.	B. Metastatic Prostate Carcinoma:
o	Prostate cancer typically causes osteoblastic metastases, which are strongly Tc-99m-MDP positive, not negative.
3.	C. Paget's Disease:
o	Paget's disease shows a mixed lytic-sclerotic pattern, with increased Tc-99m-MDP uptake due to increased bone turnover. It is unlikely to be PET-positive and solely osteolytic.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered an unsealed source therapeutic radiopharmaceutical?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer – C. 223 Ra dichloride 

Unsealed source therapeutic radiopharmaceuticals are radioactive agents administered in liquid form, which disperse throughout the body to treat specific diseases (e.g., cancer).
•	223 Ra dichloride is an alpha-emitting therapeutic radiopharmaceutical used to treat metastatic bone lesions in castration-resistant prostate cancer. It is considered an unsealed source because it is injected into the bloodstream and not confined to a specific site.
Why the Other Options are Incorrect:
1.	A. 123 I NaI:
o	This is a diagnostic radiopharmaceutical used in imaging the thyroid gland. It is not used for therapeutic purposes.
2.	B. 68 Ga DOTATATE:
o	This is a diagnostic radiopharmaceutical used in PET imaging for neuroendocrine tumors, not for therapy.
3.	D. 137 Cs seeds:
o	These are sealed source radiopharmaceuticals used in brachytherapy (internal radiation therapy), where radioactive seeds are implanted directly into or near a tumor. They are not unsealed.
Key Characteristics of Unsealed Sources:
•	Used for systemic therapy, such as targeting bone metastases or thyroid tissue.
•	Examples include:
o	131 I for thyroid cancer or hyperthyroidism.
o	223 Ra dichloride for bone metastases.

questions.text: What is the MOST likely diagnosis in this 10-year-old boy presenting with headache and abnormal vision?
questions.solution: Correct Answer– A. Craniopharyngioma The images provided suggest a lesion in the suprasellar region, commonly involving structures like the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and optic chiasm. In a 10-year-old boy presenting with headache and abnormal vision, the features strongly point to craniopharyngioma. Key Features of Craniopharyngioma: • Age Group: Most common in children and young adults. • Location: Arises in the suprasellar region, close to the optic chiasm and hypothalamus. • Symptoms: o Headache (due to increased intracranial pressure). o Visual abnormalities (from optic chiasm compression). o Endocrine dysfunction (due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis involvement). • Radiologic Features: o CT: Mixed solid and cystic mass with calcifications (common finding). o MRI: Heterogeneous appearance with cystic and solid components, often with enhancement post-contrast. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: 1. B. Rathke cleft cyst: o Typically non-calcified and purely cystic. o Usually asymptomatic unless large enough to cause compression. 2. C. Hypothalamic/chiasmatic glioma: o Commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). o Appears as an infiltrative lesion on imaging without calcifications. 3. D. Suprasellar arachnoid cyst: o Purely cystic lesion without solid components or calcifications. o Less likely to cause symptoms in this age group.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for this 8-year-old boy presenting with a limp?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - C. Radiofrequency ablation Used for painful benign bone tumors like osteoid osteoma

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman has an ultrasound examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Anencephaly The ultrasound images provided are characteristic of anencephaly, a neural tube defect resulting in the failure of the cranial end of the neural tube to close. Key Features of Anencephaly: 1. Ultrasound Findings: o Absence of the cranial vault and most of the brain tissue above the orbits. o The "frog-like" appearance of the fetus due to the absence of the skull and brain. o Polyhydramnios is often associated due to impaired swallowing by the fetus. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: 1. A. Meningomyelocele: o A neural tube defect characterized by herniation of the spinal cord and meninges through a defect in the vertebral column (usually lumbosacral). o On ultrasound, this would appear as a cystic structure with neural tissue at the lower back, not the cranial region. 2. C. Encephalocele: o A herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull, typically occipital or frontal. o Ultrasound would show a mass protruding from the skull, often cystic or solid in appearance, rather than complete absence of the cranial vault. 3. D. Alobar Holoprosencephaly: o A forebrain developmental anomaly where the brain fails to divide into two hemispheres. o Ultrasound shows a single large midline ventricle and facial abnormalities (e.g., cyclopia, proboscis).

questions.text: A 46-year-old-man presents with acute flank pain and hematuria. What is the most appropriate next imaging test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - C. Unenhanced CT scan

For a patient presenting with acute flank pain and hematuria, the most likely clinical suspicion is renal colic due to urolithiasis (kidney stones). The unenhanced CT scan (CT KUB) is the gold standard imaging test in this scenario.
Rationale for Using Unenhanced CT:
1.	High Sensitivity and Specificity:
o	Unenhanced CT is highly accurate for detecting renal and ureteric stones.
o	It allows visualization of the size, location, and density of the stones.
2.	No Contrast Required:
o	Contrast media can obscure the stones and is unnecessary for the initial diagnosis of urolithiasis.
o	Additionally, patients with potential impaired renal function or contraindications to contrast are safeguarded.
3.	Quick and Readily Available:
o	CT KUB provides rapid results, which is critical in the acute setting.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections. His abdominal CT scan is shown below. Which of the following most likely prevented the proper ascent of the anomalous organ seen on the CT scan?
questions.solution: Correct Answer - B. Inferior mesenteric artery The normal ascent of the kidneys allows the organs to take their place in the abdomen below the adrenal glands. However, with a horseshoe kidney, ascent into the abdomen is restricted by the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) which hooks over the isthmus. Hence horseshoe kidneys are low lying.

questions.text: Prophylactic intracranial radiation is indicated in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer – C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma

Prophylactic cranial irradiation (PCI) is a type of radiation therapy used to prevent the spread (metastasis) of lung cancer from the lungs to the brain. Small cell lung cancer has a strong tendency to spread to the brain. Although chemotherapy is usually good at controlling the disease (at least for a while), the drugs have difficulty penetrating the blood-brain barrier that surrounds and protects the brain. Because of this, cancer cells that enter the brain have an opportunity to proliferate. Roughly 10% of people with SCLC have brain metastases at the time of diagnosis, while 50% will develop brain metastases during the course of their disease, according to a 2017 review in Current Oncology.Prophylactic cranial irradiation ("prophylactic" meaning preventive) is meant to reduce the odds of brain metastasis proliferation by preventing the growth of cancer cells before there are any signs or indications of metastasis.

questions.text: A 30 year old with BMI 18 with progressive difficulty in swallowing in both solids and liquids for 8 months. Barium swallow is shown to you. What other investigation should be done in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer – A. UGI endoscopy + Manometry This is classic picture of achalasia cardia Manometry is indicated for confirmation of diagnosis. Achalasia: barium swallow study may be used to confirm oesophageal dilatation, in addition to assessing for mucosal abnormalities. Findings include: 1. bird beak sign or rat tail sign 2. oesophageal dilatation 3. tram track appearance: central longitudinal lucency bounded by barium on both sides 4. incomplete lower oesophageal sphincter relaxation that is not coordinated with oesophageal contraction 5. pooling or stasis of barium in the oesophagus when the oesophagus has become atonic or non-contractile (a late feature in the disease) 6. uncoordinated, non-propulsive, tertiary contractions
